revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2007}} [[File:Michelangelos David.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Michelangelo]]'s ''[[Michelangelo's David|David]]'']] [[File:TheWestWindByGould.jpg|thumb|upright|''The West Wind'', by [[Thomas Ridgeway Gould]] (American, 1818 - 1881); see also [[:File:TheWestWindByGouldSide.jpg|profile view]]]] [[File:Pollaiuolo nude warriors in combat-1470-80-.jpg|thumb|Nude warriors in combat, by [[Antonio Pollaiuolo]]]] In [[aesthetics]], the '''human figure''' or '''human form''' in art, sculpture and other art forms involves a study and appreciation of the [[beauty]] of the [[human]] body in its depiction or presentation. The study involves an appreciation of the [[Human body shape|body shape]], including [[Human positions|body postures]] - sitting, standing or even sleeping, and movements - [[Human gait|walking]], running, [[dancing]] etc. [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] refers to the human figure as the ideal of beauty.<ref>[http://www.aesthetics-online.org/ideas/leddy.html Section 17, Immanuel Kant]</ref> The human figure conforms very well to the law that states that [[form follows function]], which is believed to be a result of [[evolution]] over thousands of generations.
== Study == The human figure is one of the most enduring themes in the visual arts. Very few art forms are not related to human figure such as [[music]], though it figures in [[lyrics]]. A study of the human figure includes a detailed study of the following subjects: * [[Sculpture]]<ref>[http://www.prm.ox.ac.uk/HumanForm.html Human figure in various art forms]</ref> is similar to figure drawing. * [[Figure drawing]] involves the depiction of the body in different postures or in motion or at work. * [[Literature]] involves the description of the human figure to imply its [[sexual attraction]], physical ability and mentality. * [[Dance]] is an [[art form]] that involves [[Motion (physics)|movement]] of the body, usually rhythmic and to music,<ref>[http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9110116/dance Britannica.com]</ref> used as a form of [[Emotional expression|expression]], [[social]] [[Interpersonal relationship|interaction]] or presented in a [[spirituality|spiritual]] or [[performance]] setting. * [[Body language]] involves [[human position|body posture]], [[gesture]]s, [[facial expression]]s, and [[eye movement (sensory)|eye movements]]. * [[Fashion]] and [[Fashion accessory|accessories]]. * [[Ergonomics]] in passenger vehicles and seatings, this deals with [[unisex]] approach to human figure. * [[Gait analysis]] * [[3D animation]]
== Body proportions == {{Main|Body proportions}} ''Body proportions'' are the study of relation of [[human anatomy|human body]],<ref>[http://realcolorwheel.com/human.htm Human Proportions]</ref> or in general, animal body, parts to each other and the whole, essential for depiction of the overall figure.
== Sculpture and figure drawing == [[File:Carracci, Annibale - Studio di nudo.jpg|thumb|Nude study, by [[Annibale Carracci]]]] {{See also|Sculpture|figure drawing}} A [[figure drawing]] is a study of the human form in its various shapes and postures. It is a study or stylized depiction of the human form, with the line and form of the human figure as the primary objective, rather than the subject person. It is a composed image of the subject in a still position. A life drawing is a work that has been drawn from an observation of a live [[Model (art)|model]].
== See also == *[[Body proportions]] *[[Figure drawing]] *[[Female body shape]] *[[Human body shape]]
== Notes == * [http://www.google.com/search?q=human%20figure%20aesthetics] * [http://eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/custom/portlets/recordDetails/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=ED370857&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=eric_accno&accno=ED370857 Aesthetic Preference for Human Figures]
== References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Human Figure (Aesthetics)}} [[Category:Human body]] [[Category:Human appearance]] [[Category:Aesthetics]] [[Category:Arts]]

[[File:Chemosynthetic Microbial Mats.jpg|thumb|316x316px|Chemosynthetic microbial mats at the junction between Hydrothermal Vent and Coral Reef communities]] The '''Hydrothermal vent microbial community''' encompasses all unicellular organisms that live and reproduce in a chemically distinct area around [[Hydrothermal vent|Hydrothermal vents]]. These include organisms in the [[microbial mat]], free floating cells, or bacteria in an [[Endosymbiont|endosymbiotic]] relationship with animals. Chemolithoautotrophic bacteria derive nutrients and energy from the geological activity at Hydrothermal vents to fix carbon into organic forms. Viruses are also a part of the hydrothermal vent microbial community and their influence on the microbial ecology in these ecosystems is a burgeoning field of research.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Rika E.|last2=Brazelton|first2=William J.|last3=Baross|first3=John A.|date=2011|title=Is the genetic landscape of the deep subsurface biosphere affected by viruses?|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22084639|journal=Frontiers in Microbiology|volume=2|pages=219|doi=10.3389/fmicb.2011.00219|issn=1664-302X|pmc=3211056|pmid=22084639}}</ref>
Hydrothermal vents are located where the tectonic plates are moving apart and spreading. This allows water from the ocean to enter into the crust of the earth where it is heated by the magma. The increasing pressure and temperature forces the water back out of these openings, on the way out, the water accumulates dissolved minerals and chemicals from the rocks that it encounters. There are generally three kinds of vents that occur and are all characterized by its temperature and chemical composition. Diffuse vents release clear water typically up to 30°C. White smoker vents emit a milky coloured water that are approximately 200-330°C, black smoker vents generally release water hotter than the others between 300-400°C. The waters from black smokers are darkened by the precipitates of sulfide that are accumulated.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lutz|first=Richard A.|last2=Kennish|first2=Michael J.|date=1993|title=Ecology of deep-sea hydrothermal vent communities: A review|journal=Reviews of Geophysics|language=en|volume=31|issue=3|pages=211|doi=10.1029/93rg01280|issn=8755-1209}}</ref> Due to there not being any sunlight at these ocean depths, energy is provided by [[chemosynthesis]] where symbiotic bacteria and archaea form the bottom of the food chain and are able to support a variety of organisms such as Riftia pachyptila and Alvinella pompejana. These organisms utilize this symbiotic relationship in order to utilize and obtain the chemical energy that is released at these hydrothermal vent areas.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kádár|first=Enikõ|last2=Costa|first2=Valentina|last3=Santos|first3=Ricardo S.|last4=Powell|first4=Jonathan J.|date=July 2006|title=Tissue partitioning of micro-essential metals in the vent bivalve Bathymodiolus azoricus and associated organisms (endosymbiont bacteria and a parasite polychaete) from geochemically distinct vents of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.seares.2006.01.002|journal=Journal of Sea Research|volume=56|issue=1|pages=45–52|doi=10.1016/j.seares.2006.01.002|issn=1385-1101}}</ref> == Environmental Properties == [[File:Expl1296 - Flickr - NOAA Photo Library.jpg|thumb|236x236px|A cloud of effluent being expelled by a hydrothermal vent violently.|alt=|left]]Although there is a large variation in temperatures at the surface of the water with the changing depths of the [[thermocline]] seasonally, the temperatures underneath the thermocline and the waters near the deep sea are relatively constant. There aren’t any changes that are brought about by seasonal effects or annual changes. These temperatures stay in the range of 0-3°C with the exception of the waters immediately surrounding the hydrothermal vents which can get as high as 407°C.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.windows2universe.org/?page=/earth/water/temp.html|title=Temperature of Ocean Water - Windows to the Universe|website=www.windows2universe.org|access-date=2018-10-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Haase|first=K. M.|last2=Petersen|first2=S.|last3=Koschinsky|first3=A.|last4=Seifert|first4=R.|last5=Devey|first5=C. W.|last6=Keir|first6=R.|last7=Lackschewitz|first7=K. S.|last8=Melchert|first8=B.|last9=Perner|first9=M.|date=November 2007|title=Young volcanism and related hydrothermal activity at 5°S on the slow-spreading southern Mid-Atlantic Ridge|url=https://doi.org/10.1029/2006GC001509|journal=Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems|language=en|volume=8|issue=11|pages=n/a–n/a|doi=10.1029/2006gc001509|issn=1525-2027}}</ref> These waters are prevented from boiling due to the pressure that is acting upon it at those depths.
With increasing depth, the effects of pressure start to occur. The pressure is due to the weight of water above pushing down. The approximate rate of pressure increase in the ocean is 10Mega-pascals (MPa) for every kilometre that is traveled towards the seafloor. This means that [[Hydrostatics|hydrostatic pressure]] can reach up to 110MPa at the depths of the trenches.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jebbar|first=Mohamed|last2=Franzetti|first2=Bruno|last3=Girard|first3=Eric|last4=Oger|first4=Philippe|date=2015-06-23|title=Microbial diversity and adaptation to high hydrostatic pressure in deep-sea hydrothermal vents prokaryotes|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00792-015-0760-3|journal=Extremophiles|language=en|volume=19|issue=4|pages=721–740|doi=10.1007/s00792-015-0760-3|issn=1431-0651}}</ref>
Salinity stay relatively constant within the deep seas communities around the world at 35parts per thousand (ppt).<ref name=":0" />
There is no light in the hydrothermal vent environment so there are no organisms that can create energy from photosynthesis. Instead, the energy that the majority of organisms utilize comes from chemosynthesis. The organisms utilize the minerals and chemicals that come out of the vents.
== Adaptations == Extreme conditions in the hydrothermal vent environment means that microbial communities that inhabit these areas need to adapt to them. Microbes that live here are known to be hyperthermophiles which by definition are microorganisms that grow at temperatures above 90°C. These organisms are found where the fluids from the vents are expelled and mixed with the surrounding water. These hyperthermophilic microbes are thought to contain proteins that have extended stability at higher temperatures due to intramolecular interactions but the exact mechanisms are not clear yet. The stabilization mechanisms for DNA are not as unknown and the denaturation of DNA are thought to be minimized through high salt concentrations, more specifically Mg, K, and PO4 which are highly concentrated in hyperthermophiles. Along with this, many of the microbes have proteins similar to histones that are bound to the DNA and can offer protection against the high temperatures. Microbes are also found to be in symbiotic relationships with other organisms in the hydrothermal vent environment due to their ability to have a detoxification mechanism which allows them to metabolize the sulfide-rich waters which would otherwise be toxic to the organisms and the microbes.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zierenberg|first=Robert A.|last2=Adams|first2=Michael W. W.|last3=Arp|first3=Alissa J.|date=2000-11-21|title=Life in extreme environments: Hydrothermal vents|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/97/24/12961|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=97|issue=24|pages=12961–12962|doi=10.1073/pnas.210395997|issn=0027-8424|pmc=34077|pmid=11058150}}</ref>
== Microbial Biogeochemistry ==
=== Introduction === [[File:Deep sea vent chemistry diagram.jpg|right|thumb|388x388px|A diagram showing the process of how seawater becomes a part of the hydrothermal effluent including the elements that are added and precipitated.]]Microbial communities at hydrothermal vents mediate the transformation of energy and minerals produced by geological activity into [[Organic matter|organic material]]. Organic matter produced by [[Autotroph|autotrophic]] bacteria is then used to support the upper [[Trophic level|trophic levels]]. The hydrothermal vent fluid and the surrounding ocean water is rich in elements such as [[iron]], [[manganese]] and various species of sulfur including [[sulfide]], [[sulfite]], [[sulfate]], [[Sulfur|elemental sulfur]] from which they can derive energy or nutrients.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Kletzin|first=Arnulf|last2=Urich|first2=Tim|last3=Müller|first3=Fabian|last4=Bandeiras|first4=Tiago M.|last5=Gomes|first5=Cláudio M.|date=February 2004|title=Dissimilatory oxidation and reduction of elemental sulfur in thermophilic archaea|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15168612|journal=Journal of Bioenergetics and Biomembranes|volume=36|issue=1|pages=77–91|issn=0145-479X|pmid=15168612}}</ref> Microbes derive energy by [[Redox|oxidizing or reducing]] elements. Different microbial species utilize different [[chemical species]] of an element in their [[Metabolism|metabolic]] processes. For example, some microbe species oxidize sulfide to sulfate and another species will reduce sulfate to elemental sulfur. As a result, a web of chemical pathways mediated by different microbial species transform elements such as carbon, sulfur, nitrogen, and hydrogen, from one species to another. Their activity alters the original chemical composition produced by geological activity of the hydrothermal vent environment.<ref name=":2" />
=== Carbon Cycle === Refer to [[Carbon cycle|Carbon Cycle]]
Geological activity at hydrothermal vents produce an abundance of [[Compounds of carbon|carbon compounds]].<ref name=":4" /> Hydrothermal vent plumes contain high concentrations of [[methane]] and [[carbon monoxide]] with methane concentration reaching 10<sup>7</sup> times of the surrounding ocean water.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":9" /> [[Deep ocean water]] is also a large reservoir of carbon and concentration of carbon dioxide species such as dissolved CO<sub>2</sub> and HCO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> around 2.2mM.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dunk|first=Rachel M.|last2=Peltzer|first2=Edward T.|last3=Walz|first3=Peter M.|last4=Brewer|first4=Peter G.|date=2005-12-15|title=Seeing a deep ocean CO2 enrichment experiment in a new light: laser raman detection of dissolved CO2 in seawater|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16475344|journal=Environmental Science & Technology|volume=39|issue=24|pages=9630–9636|issn=0013-936X|pmid=16475344}}</ref> The bountiful carbon and electron acceptors produced by geological activity support an oasis of [[Chemotroph|chemoautotrophic]] microbial communities that fix inorganic carbon, such as CO<sub>2,</sub> using energy from sources such as oxidation of sulfur, iron, manganese, hydrogen and methane.<ref name=":4" /> These bacteria supply a large portion of organic carbon that support [[Heterotroph|heterotrophic]] life at hydrothermal vents.<ref name=":14" />
==== Carbon Fixation ==== [[Carbon fixation]] is the incorporation of inorganic carbon into organic matter. Unlike the surface of the planet where light is a major source of energy for carbon fixation, hydrothermal vent chemolithotrophic bacteria rely on chemical oxidation to obtain the energy required.<ref name=":5" /> Fixation of CO<sub>2</sub> is observed in members of [[Gammaproteobacteria|gammaproteobacterial]], [[epsilonproteobacteria]], [[alphaproteobacteria]], and members of [[Archaea]] domain at hydrothermal vents. Four major [[Metabolic pathway|metabolic pathways]] for carbon fixation found in microbial vent communities include the Calvin–Benson–Bassham (CBB) cycle, reductive tricarboxylic acid (rTCA) cycle, 3-hydroxypropionate (3-HP) cycle and reductive acetyl coenzyme A (acetyl-CoA) pathway.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Nakagawa|first=Satoshi|last2=Takai|first2=Ken|date=July 2008|title=Deep-sea vent chemoautotrophs: diversity, biochemistry and ecological significance|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18503548|journal=FEMS microbiology ecology|volume=65|issue=1|pages=1–14|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6941.2008.00502.x|issn=0168-6496|pmid=18503548}}</ref>
===== Carbon Fixation Metabolic Pathways ===== :'''Calvin-Benson-Bassham cycle (CBB)'''
::The [[Light-independent reactions|Calvin-Benson-Bassham (CBB)]] cycle is the most common CO<sub>2</sub> fixation pathway found among autotrophs.<ref name=":8" /> The key [[enzyme]] is ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase ([[RuBisCO]]).<ref name=":5" /> [[RuBisCO]] has been identified in members of the microbial community such as ''Thiomicrospira, [[Beggiatoa]]''[[Beggiatoa|,]] ''[[Zetaproteobacteria|zetaproteobacterium]]'', and [[Gammaproteobacteria|gammaproteobacterial]] [[Endosymbiont|endosymbionts]] of [[Tube worm|tubeworms]], [[Bivalvia|bivalves]], and [[Gastropoda|gastropods]].<ref name=":8" />
:'''Reductive Carboxylic Acid Cycle (rTCA)'''
::The [[Reverse Krebs cycle|Reductive Carboxylic Acid Cycle (rTCA)]] is the second most commonly found carbon fixation pathway at hydrothermal vents.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Cerqueira|first=Teresa|last2=Barroso|first2=Cristina|last3=Froufe|first3=Hugo|last4=Egas|first4=Conceição|last5=Bettencourt|first5=Raul|date=August 2018|title=Metagenomic Signatures of Microbial Communities in Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Sediments of Azores Vent Fields|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29354879|journal=Microbial Ecology|volume=76|issue=2|pages=387–403|doi=10.1007/s00248-018-1144-x|issn=1432-184X|pmid=29354879}}</ref> rTCA cycle is essentially a reversed [[Citric acid cycle|TCA or Kreb cycle]] heterotrophs use to oxidize organic matter. Organism that use the rTCA cycle prefer to inhabit [[Anoxic waters|anoxic]] zones in the hydrothermal vent system because some enzymes in the rTCA cycle are sensitive to the presence of O<sub>2.</sub><ref name=":5" /> It is found in sulfate reducing [[Deltaproteobacteria|deltaproteobacterium]] such as some members of ''[[Desulfobacterium|Desulfobacter]]'', ''[[Aquificae|Aquificales]]'' and ''[[Aquifex]]'' and ''[[Thermoproteales]]''.<ref name=":5" />
:'''3-HP and 3-HP/4-HB cycles'''
::The key enzymes of [[3-HP and 3-HP/4-HB]] cycles are acetyl-CoA/propionyl-CoA carboxylase, malonyl-CoA reductase and propionyl-CoA synthase. Most of the organisms that use this pathway are [[Mixotroph|mixotrophs]] with the ability to utilize organic carbon in addition to carbon fixation.<ref name=":5" />
:'''Reductive Acetyl CoA pathway'''
::The [[Wood–Ljungdahl pathway|Reductive Acetyl CoA]] pathway has only been found in chemoautotrophs. This pathway does not require [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] as the pathway is directly coupled to the reduction of H<sub>2</sub>. Organisms that have been found with this pathway prefer H<sub>2</sub> rich areas. Species include deltaproteobacterium such as ''[[Dulfobacterium autotrophicum]],'' [[acetogen]]<nowiki/>s and [[Methanogen|methanogenic]] ''Archaea''.<ref name=":5" />
==== Methane Metabolism ==== Hydrothermal vents produce high quantities of [[methane]] which can originate from both geological and biological processes.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":9">de Angelis, M. A. (1989). ''Studies of microbial methane oxidation in deep sea hydrothermal vent environments'' (Order No. 9020909). Available from ProQuest Dissertations & Theses Global. (303750552). Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/303750552</ref> Methane concentrations in hydrothermal vent plumes can exceed 300µM in concentration depending on the vent. In comparison, the vent fluid contains 10<sup>6</sup> – 10<sup>7</sup> times more methane than the surrounding deep ocean water, of which methane ranges between 0.2-0.3nM in concentration.<ref name=":9" /> Microbial communities utilize the high concentrations of methane as an energy source and a source of carbon.<ref name=":4" /> [[Methanotroph|Methanotrophy]], where a species uses methane both as an energy and carbon source, have been observed with the presence of [[gammaproteobacteria]] in the ''[[Methylococcaceae]]'' lineages.<ref name=":8" /> Methanotrophs convert methane into carbon dioxide and organic carbon.<ref name=":9" /> They are typically characterized by the presence of intercellular membranes and microbes with intercellular membranes were observed to make up 20% of the [[microbial mat]] at hydrothermal vents.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":9" />
===== Methane Oxidation ===== Energy generation via methane oxidation yields the next best source of energy after sulfur oxidation.<ref name=":4" /> It has been suggested that microbial oxidation facilitates rapid turnover at hydrothermal vents, thus much of the methane is oxidize within short distance of the vent.<ref name=":9" /> In hydrothermal vent communities, aerobic oxidation of methane is commonly found in [[Endosymbiont|endosymbiotic]] microbes of vent animals.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Martin|first=William|last2=Baross|first2=John|last3=Kelley|first3=Deborah|last4=Russell|first4=Michael J.|date=November 2008|title=Hydrothermal vents and the origin of life|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18820700|journal=Nature Reviews. Microbiology|volume=6|issue=11|pages=805–814|doi=10.1038/nrmicro1991|issn=1740-1534|pmid=18820700}}</ref> [[Anaerobic oxidation of methane]] (AOM) is typically coupled to reduction of sulfate or Fe and Mn as [[Electron acceptor|terminal electron acceptors]] as these are most plentiful at hydrothermal vents.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Wankel|first=Scott D.|last2=Adams|first2=Melissa M.|last3=Johnston|first3=David T.|last4=Hansel|first4=Colleen M.|last5=Joye|first5=Samantha B.|last6=Girguis|first6=Peter R.|date=October 2012|title=Anaerobic methane oxidation in metalliferous hydrothermal sediments: influence on carbon flux and decoupling from sulfate reduction|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22827909|journal=Environmental Microbiology|volume=14|issue=10|pages=2726–2740|doi=10.1111/j.1462-2920.2012.02825.x|issn=1462-2920|pmid=22827909}}</ref> AOM is found to be prevalent in marine sediments at hydrothermal vents<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Biddle|first=Jennifer F.|last2=Cardman|first2=Zena|last3=Mendlovitz|first3=Howard|last4=Albert|first4=Daniel B.|last5=Lloyd|first5=Karen G.|last6=Boetius|first6=Antje|last7=Teske|first7=Andreas|date=May 2012|title=Anaerobic oxidation of methane at different temperature regimes in Guaymas Basin hydrothermal sediments|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22094346|journal=The ISME journal|volume=6|issue=5|pages=1018–1031|doi=10.1038/ismej.2011.164|issn=1751-7370|pmc=3329104|pmid=22094346}}</ref><ref name=":11" /> and may be responsible for consuming 75% of methane produced by the vent.<ref name=":11" /> Species that perform AOM include Archaea of [[Phylum|phyllum]] ''[[Crenarchaeota]]'' and ''[[Thermococcus]]''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brazelton|first=William J.|last2=Schrenk|first2=Matthew O.|last3=Kelley|first3=Deborah S.|last4=Baross|first4=John A.|date=September 2006|title=Methane- and sulfur-metabolizing microbial communities dominate the Lost City hydrothermal field ecosystem|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16957253|journal=Applied and Environmental Microbiology|volume=72|issue=9|pages=6257–6270|doi=10.1128/AEM.00574-06|issn=0099-2240|pmc=1563643|pmid=16957253}}</ref>''.''
===== Methanogenesis ===== Production of methane through [[methanogenesis]] can be from degradation of [[Hydrocarbon|hydrocarbons]], from reaction of carbon dioxide or other compounds like [[formate]].<ref name=":10" /> Evidence of methanogenesis can be found alongside of AOM in sediments.<ref name=":13" /> [[Thermophile|Thermophilic methanogens]] are found to grow in Hydrothermal vent plumes at temperatures between 55<sup>o</sup>C to 80<sup>o</sup>C.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Topçuoğlu|first=Begüm D.|last2=Stewart|first2=Lucy C.|last3=Morrison|first3=Hilary G.|last4=Butterfield|first4=David A.|last5=Huber|first5=Julie A.|last6=Holden|first6=James F.|date=2016|title=Hydrogen Limitation and Syntrophic Growth among Natural Assemblages of Thermophilic Methanogens at Deep-sea Hydrothermal Vents|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27547206|journal=Frontiers in Microbiology|volume=7|pages=1240|doi=10.3389/fmicb.2016.01240|issn=1664-302X|pmc=4974244|pmid=27547206}}</ref> However, [[Autotroph|autotropic]] methanogenesis performed by many thermophilic species require H<sub>2</sub> as an electron donor so microbial growth is limited by H<sub>2</sub> availability.<ref name=":12" /><ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Ver Eecke|first=Helene C.|last2=Butterfield|first2=David A.|last3=Huber|first3=Julie A.|last4=Lilley|first4=Marvin D.|last5=Olson|first5=Eric J.|last6=Roe|first6=Kevin K.|last7=Evans|first7=Leigh J.|last8=Merkel|first8=Alexandr Y.|last9=Cantin|first9=Holly V.|date=2012-08-21|title=Hydrogen-limited growth of hyperthermophilic methanogens at deep-sea hydrothermal vents|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22869718|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=109|issue=34|pages=13674–13679|doi=10.1073/pnas.1206632109|issn=1091-6490|pmc=3427048|pmid=22869718}}</ref> Genera of thermophilic methanogens found at hydrothermal vents include ''[[Methanocaldococcus]], [[Methanothermococcus]]'', and ''[[Methanococcus]]''.<ref name=":12" /> [[File:Sulfur Cycle for Hydrothermal Vents.png|thumb|368x368px|The sulfur cycle processes relevant to hydrothermal vent microbial communities with examples of phyla/genera.]]
=== Sulfur Cycle === Refer to [[Sulfur cycle|Sulfur Cycle]]
Microbial communities at hydrothermal vent convert sulfur such as [[Sulfuric acid|H<sub>2</sub>S]] produced by geological activity into other forms such as [[sulfite]], [[sulfate]], and [[Sulfur|elemental sulfur]] for energy or [[Assimilation (biology)|assimilation]] into [[Organic compound|organic molecules]].<ref name=":2" /> Sulfide is plentiful at Hydrothermal Vents, with concentrations from one to tens of mM, whereas the surrounding ocean water usually only contains a few nano molars.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Radford-Knoery|first=Joël|last2=German|first2=C. R.|last3=Charlou|first3=J.-L.|last4=Donval|first4=J.-P.|last5=Fouquet|first5=Y.|date=March 2001|title=Distribution and behavior of dissolved hydrogen sulfide in hydrothermal plumes|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.4319/lo.2001.46.2.0461|journal=Limnology and Oceanography|language=en|volume=46|issue=2|pages=461–464|doi=10.4319/lo.2001.46.2.0461|issn=0024-3590}}</ref>
==== Sulfur Oxidation ==== Refer to [[Microbial oxidation of sulfur|Microbial Oxidation of Sulfur]]
Reduced sulfur compounds such as H<sub>2</sub>S produced by the hydrothermal vents are a major source of energy for sulfur metabolism in microbes.<ref name=":4" /> [[Redox|Oxidation]] of reduced sulfur compounds into forms such as [[sulfite]], [[thiosulfate]], and elemental sulfur is used to produce energy for microbe metabolism such as synthesis of [[Organic compound|organic compounds]] from [[Compounds of carbon|inorganic carbon]].<ref name=":2" /> The major metabolic pathways used for sulfur oxidation includes the [[Microbial oxidation of sulfur#%20Biochemistry|''SOX'' pathway]] and dissimilatory oxidation. The Sox pathway is a multi enzyme pathway capable of oxidizing sulfide, sulfite, elemental sulfur, and thiosulfate to sulfate.<ref name=":2" /> Dissimilatory oxidation converts sulfite to elemental sulfur.<ref name=":1" /> Sulfur oxidizing species include and the genera of ''[[Thiomicrospira aerophila|Thiomicrospira]], [[Halothiobacillus]], [[Beggiatoa]], [[Persephonella marina|Persephonella]],'' and ''[[Sulfurimonas]].'' [[Symbiosis|Symbiotic]] species of the class ''[[Gammaproteobacteria]], [[Epsilonproteobacteria|EpsilonproteobacteriaI]]'' can also oxidize sulfur.<ref name=":2">{{Citation|last=Sievert|first=Stefan M.|title=Sulfur Oxidation at Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Vents|date=2008|url=https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-540-72682-1_19|work=Microbial Sulfur Metabolism|pages=238–258|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|language=en|doi=10.1007/978-3-540-72682-1_19|isbn=9783540726791|access-date=2018-10-19|last2=Hügler|first2=Michael|last3=Taylor|first3=Craig D.|last4=Wirsen|first4=Carl O.}}</ref>
==== Sulfur Reduction ==== [[Dissimilatory sulfate reduction|Sulfur reduction]] uses sulfate as an electron acceptor for the [[Sulfur assimilation|assimilation of sulfur]]. Microbes that perform sulfate reduction typically use [[hydrogen]], [[methane]] or organic matter as an [[electron donor]].<ref name=":11" /><ref name=":3" /> [[Anaerobic oxidation of methane]] (AOM) often use sulfate as electron acceptor.<ref name=":11" /> This method is favoured by organisms living in highly [[Anoxic waters|anoxic]] areas of the hydrothermal vent,<ref name=":3" /> thus are one of the predominate processes that occur within the sediments.<ref name=":14" /> Species that reduce sulfate have been identified in [[Archaea]] and members of [[Deltaproteobacteria]] such as ''[[Desulfovibrio]], [[Desulfobulbus propionicus|Desulfobulbus]], [[Desulfobacteraceae|Desulfobacteria]], and [[Desulfuromonas]]'' at hydrothermal vents<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Frank|first=Kiana L.|last2=Rogers|first2=Daniel R.|last3=Olins|first3=Heather C.|last4=Vidoudez|first4=Charles|last5=Girguis|first5=Peter R.|date=July 2013|title=Characterizing the distribution and rates of microbial sulfate reduction at Middle Valley hydrothermal vents|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23535916|journal=The ISME journal|volume=7|issue=7|pages=1391–1401|doi=10.1038/ismej.2013.17|issn=1751-7370|pmc=3695286|pmid=23535916}}</ref>
''' ''' [[File:Nitrogen cycle of hydrothermal vents 2.png|thumb|401x401px|Processes of the nitrogen cycle relevant to microbial communities at hydrothermal vents, including names of pyla/genera. Adapted from Gruber et al. (2008)]]
=== Nitrogen Cycle === Refer to [[Nitrogen cycle|Nitrogen Cycle]]
Deep ocean water contains the largest reservoir of [[nitrogen]] available to hydrothermal vents with around 0.59 mM of dissolved [[Nitrogen|Nitrogen gas]].<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Mehta|first=Mausmi P.|last2=Butterfield|first2=David A.|last3=Baross|first3=John A.|date=February 2003|title=Phylogenetic diversity of nitrogenase (nifH) genes in deep-sea and hydrothermal vent environments of the Juan de Fuca Ridge|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12571018|journal=Applied and Environmental Microbiology|volume=69|issue=2|pages=960–970|doi=10.1128/AEM.69.2.960-970.2003|issn=0099-2240|pmc=143675|pmid=12571018}}</ref><ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=Bourbonnais|first=Annie|last2=Lehmann|first2=Moritz F.|last3=Butterfield|first3=David A.|last4=Juniper|first4=S. Kim|date=February 2012|title=Subseafloor nitrogen transformations in diffuse hydrothermal vent fluids of the Juan de Fuca Ridge evidenced by the isotopic composition of nitrate and ammonium|url=https://doi.org/10.1029/2011GC003863|journal=Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems|language=en|volume=13|issue=2|pages=n/a–n/a|doi=10.1029/2011gc003863|issn=1525-2027}}</ref> [[Ammonium]] is the dominate species of dissolved inorganic nitrogen and can be produced by water mass mixing below hydrothermal vents and discharged in vent fluids.<ref name=":16" /> Quantities of available ammonium varies with each vent depending on the geological activity and microbial composition.<ref name=":16" /> [[Nitrate]] and [[nitrite]] concentrations are depleted in hydrothermal vents compared to the surrounding seawater.<ref name=":15" />
The study of the [[Nitrogen cycle|Nitrogen Cycle]] in hydrothermal vent microbial communities still requires more comprehensive research.<ref name=":15" /> However, [[isotope]] data suggests that microorganism influence dissolved inorganic nitrogen quantities and compositions and all pathways of the nitrogen cycle are likely to be found at hydrothermal vents.<ref name=":16" /> Biological [[nitrogen fixation]] is important to provide some of the biologically available nitrogen to the nitrogen cycle especially at unsedimented hydrothermal vents.<ref name=":15" /> Nitrogen fixation is done by many different microbes including [[methanogen]] in the orders ''[[Methanomicrobiales]]'', ''[[Methanococcales]]'', and ''[[Methanobacteriales]]''<ref name=":15" />''.'' [[Thermophile|Thermophilic]] microbes have been found to be able to fix nitrogen at higher temperatures such as 92°C.<ref name=":15" /> Nitrogen fixation may be especially prevalent in [[Microbial mat|microbial mats]] and [[Pelagic sediment|particulate material]] where biologically available levels of nitrogen are low, due to high microbe density and anaerobic environment allows the function of [[nitrogenase]], a nitrogen fixing enzyme.<ref name=":15" /> Evidence have also been detected of [[Nitrogen assimilation|assimilation]], [[nitrification]], [[denitrification]], [[Anammox|anamox]], [[Mineralization (biology)|mineralization]] and [[dissimilatory nitrate reduction to ammonium]].<ref name=":16" /> For example, [[sulfur oxidizing bacteria]] like ''Begiatoa'' species, perform denitrification and reduces nitrate to oxidize H<sub>2</sub>S.<ref name=":15" /> Nitrate assimilation is done by symbiotic species of [[Riftia pachyptila|''Riftia pachyptil''a]] tubeworm<ref name=":15" />
== Bacterial Diversity == The most abundant bacteria in hydrothermal vents are chemolithotrophs. These bacteria use reduced chemical species, most often sulfur, as sources of energy to reduce carbon dioxide to organic carbon.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Jannasch|first=Holger W.|last2=Mottl|first2=Michael J.|date=1985|title=Geomicrobiology of Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Vents|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/1696097|journal=Science|volume=229|issue=4715|pages=717–725}}</ref> The chemolithotrophic abundance in a hydrothermal vent environment is determined by the available energy sources; different temperature vents have different concentrations of nutrients, suggesting large variation between vents. In general, large microbial populations are found in warm vent water plumes (25°C), the surfaces exposed to warm vent plumes and in symbiotic tissues within certain vent invertebrates in the vicinity of the vent.<ref name=":4" />
=== Sulfur-oxidizing === These bacteria use various forms of available sulfur (S<sup>-2</sup>, S<sup>0</sup>, S<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><sup>-2</sup>) in the presence of oxygen. They are the predominant population in the majority of hydrothermal vents because their source of energy is widely available, and chemosynthesis rates increase in aerobic conditions. The bacteria at hydrothermal vents are similar to the types of sulfur bacteria found in other H<sub>2</sub>S-rich environments - except ''Thiomicrospira'' has replaced ''Thiobacillus.'' Other common species are ''Thiothrix'' and ''Beggiatoa,'' which is of particular importance because of its ability to fix nitrogen.<ref name=":4" />
=== Methane-oxidizing === Methane is a substantial source of energy in certain hydrothermal vents, but not others: methane is more abundant in warm vents (25°C) than hydrogen.<ref name=":4" /> Many types of methanotrophic bacteria exist, which require oxygen and fix CH<sub>4</sub>, CH<sub>3</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>, and other C<sub>1</sub> compounds, including CO<sub>2</sub> and CO, if present in vent water.<ref name=":4" /> These type of bacteria are also found in ''[[Riftia pachyptila|Riftia]]'' trophosome, indicating a symbiotic relationship.<ref name=":4" /> Here, methane-oxidizing bacteria refers to [[Methanotroph|methanotrophs]], which are not the same as [[Methanogen|methanogens]]: ''[[Methanococcus]]'' and ''[[Methanocaldococcus jannaschii]]'' are examples methanogens,<ref name=":4" /> which are found in hydrothermal vents; whereas ''[[Methylocystaceae]]'' are methanotrophs, which have been discovered in hydrothermal vent communities as well.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Skennerton|first=Connor T.|last2=Ward|first2=Lewis M.|last3=Michel|first3=Alice|last4=Metcalfe|first4=Kyle|last5=Valiente|first5=Chanel|last6=Mullin|first6=Sean|last7=Chan|first7=Ken Y.|last8=Gradinaru|first8=Viviana|last9=Orphan|first9=Victoria J.|date=2015|title=Genomic Reconstruction of an Uncultured Hydrothermal Vent Gammaproteobacterial Methanotroph (Family Methylothermaceae) Indicates Multiple Adaptations to Oxygen Limitation|url=https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmicb.2015.01425/full|journal=Frontiers in Microbiology|language=English|volume=6|doi=10.3389/fmicb.2015.01425|issn=1664-302X|pmc=4688376|pmid=26779119}}</ref>
=== Hydrogen-oxidizing === Little is known about microbes that use hydrogen as a source of energy, however, studies have shown that they are aerobic, and also symbiotic with ''Riftia'' (see below).<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6" /> These bacteria are important in the primary production of organic carbon because the geothermally-produced H<sub>2</sub> is taken up for this process.<ref name=":4" /> Hydrogen-oxidizing and denitrifying bacteria may be abundant in vents where NO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>-containing bottom seawater mixes with hydrothermal fluid.<ref name=":4" /> ''Desulfonauticus submarinus'' is a [[hydrogenotroph]] that reduces sulfur-compounds in warm vents and has been found in tube worms ''R. pachyptila'' and ''Alvinella pompejana.'' <ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Audiffrin|first=Carine|last2=Cayol|first2=Jean-Luc|last3=Joulian|first3=Catherine|last4=Casalot|first4=Laurence|last5=Thomas|first5=Pierre|last6=Garcia|first6=Jean-Louis|last7=Ollivier|first7=Bernard|date=2003|title=Desulfonauticus submarinus gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel sulfate-reducing bacterium isolated from a deep-sea hydrothermal vent|url=http://ijs.microbiologyresearch.org/content/journal/ijsem/10.1099/ijs.0.02551-0|journal=International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology|volume=53|issue=5|pages=1585–1590|doi=10.1099/ijs.0.02551-0}}</ref>
=== Iron- and manganese-oxidizing === These bacteria are commonly found in iron and manganese deposits on surfaces exposed intermittently to plumes of hydrothermal and bottom seawater. However, due to the rapid oxidation of Fe<sup>2+</sup> in neutral and alkaline waters (i.e. freshwater and seawater), bacteria responsible for the oxidative deposition of iron would be more commonly found in acidic waters.<ref name=":4" /> Manganese-oxidizing bacteria would be more abundant in freshwater and seawater compared to iron-oxidizing bacteria due to the higher concentration of available metal.<ref name=":4" />
=== Ecology ===
==== Symbiotic Relationships ==== [[Symbiosis|Symbiotic]] [[chemosynthesis]] is an important process for hydrothermal vent communities.<ref name=":4" /> At warm vents, common symbionts for bacteria are deep-sea clams, ''[[Calyptogena magnifica|Calpytogena magnifica]],'' mussels such as ''[[Bathymodiolus thermophilus|Bathyomodiolus thermophilus]]'' and pogonophoran tube worms, ''[[Riftia pachyptila]]'', and ''[[Alvinella pompejana]]''.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://microbewiki.kenyon.edu/index.php/Hydrothermal_vents|title=Hydrothermal vents - microbewiki|website=microbewiki.kenyon.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref><ref name=":7" />The [[trophosome]] of these animals are specified organs for symbionts that contains valuable molecules for chemosynthesis. These organisms have become so reliant on their symbionts that they have lost all morphological features relating to ingestion and digestion, though the bacteria are provided with H<sub>2</sub>S and free O<sub>2</sub>.<ref name=":4" /> Additionally, methane-oxidizing bacteria have been isolated from ''C. magnifica'' and ''R. pachyptila,'' which indicate that methane assimilation may take place within the trophosome of these organisms.<ref name=":1" />
==== Phyla and Genera ==== To illustrate the incredible diversity of hydrothermal vents, the list below is a cumulative representation of bacterial phyla and genera, in alphabetical order. As shown, proteobacteria appears to be the most dominant phyla present in deep-sea vents.
* [[Actinobacteria]]<ref name=":8" /> * [[Aquificae]] ** [[Hydrogenobacter]] and [[Aquifex]]<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":8" /> * [[Chloroflexi (phylum)|Chloroflexi]]<ref name=":8" /> * Chlorobi - [[Chlorobium]] * [[Deferribacteraceae|Deferribacteres]] * [[Gemmatimonadetes]] <ref name=":8" /> * [[Nitrospirae]] ** Nitrospinae<ref name=":8" /> ** [[Leptospirillum ferriphilum]] * [[Firmicutes]] ** Acetogen: [[Clostridium]]<ref name=":8" />
* [[Proteobacteria]] ** [[Acidithiobacillia]] ** [[Alphaproteobacteria]]<ref name=":8" /> *** [[Paracoccus]] ** [[Betaproteobacteria]] *** [[Thiobacillus]] *** Sideroxydans lithotrophicus<ref name=":8" /> ** [[Gammaproteobacteria]] - major symbionts<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":8" /> *** [[Allochromatium]] *** Thiomicrospira *** Thioalkalivibrio *** Methylococcaceae *** Beggiatoa *** Thioploca ** [[Deltaproteobacteria]] - sulfate-reducing, make up more than 25% of the bacterial community<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name=":3" /> *** Desulfovibrio *** Desulfobulbus *** Desulfuromonas ** [[Epsilonproteobacteria]]<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":8" /> *** Sulfurovum lithotrophicum *** Sulfurimonas paralvinellae *** Nitratifactor salsuginis *** Hydrogenimonas thermophila *** Thiovulum * [[Thermodesulfobacteria]]<ref name=":4" /> * [[Zetaproteobacteria]] ** [[Mariprofundus ferrooxydans]]<ref name=":5" />
== Viruses & Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Vents == [[File:High Rise black smoker.jpg|left|thumb|[[Black smoker]] in the High Rise portion of the [[Endeavour Hydrothermal Vents]].]] [[Virus|Viruses]] are the most abundant life in the ocean, harboring the greatest reservoir of genetic diversity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Suttle|first=Curtis A.|date=September 2005|title=Viruses in the sea|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nature04160|journal=Nature|volume=437|issue=7057|pages=356–361|doi=10.1038/nature04160|issn=0028-0836}}</ref> As their infections are often fatal, they constitute a significant source of mortality and thus have widespread influence on biological oceanographic processes, [[evolution]] and [[Geochemical cycle#Differentiating biogeochemical cycles|biogeochemical cycling]] within the ocean.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Suttle|first=Curtis A.|date=October 2007|title=Marine viruses — major players in the global ecosystem|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/nrmicro1750|journal=Nature Reviews Microbiology|language=En|volume=5|issue=10|pages=801–812|doi=10.1038/nrmicro1750|issn=1740-1526}}</ref> Evidence has been found however to indicate that viruses found in vent habitats have adopted a more [[Mutualism (biology)|mutualistic]] than [[Parasitism|parasitic]] evolutionary strategy in order to survive the extreme and volatile environment they exist in.<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=Rika E.|last2=Sogin|first2=Mitchell L.|last3=Baross|first3=John A.|date=2014-10-03|title=Evolutionary Strategies of Viruses, Bacteria and Archaea in Hydrothermal Vent Ecosystems Revealed through Metagenomics|url=https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article/file?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0109696|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=9|issue=10|pages=e109696|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0109696|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4184897|pmid=25279954}}</ref>
Deep-sea hydrothermal vents were found to have high numbers of viruses indicating high viral production.<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Ortmann|first=Alice C.|last2=Suttle|first2=Curtis A.|date=August 2005|title=High abundances of viruses in a deep-sea hydrothermal vent system indicates viral mediated microbial mortality|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0967063705001032|journal=Deep Sea Research Part I: Oceanographic Research Papers|volume=52|issue=8|pages=1515–1527|doi=10.1016/j.dsr.2005.04.002|issn=0967-0637}}</ref> Samples from the [[Endeavour Hydrothermal Vents]] off the coast southwest British Columbia showed that active venting [[black smokers]] had viral abundances from 1.45x10<sup>5</sup> to 9.90x10<sup>7</sup> per mL with a drop-off in abundance found in the hydrothermal-vent plume (3.5x10<sup>6</sup> per mL) and outside the venting system (2.94x10<sup>6</sup> per mL). The high number-density of viruses and therefore viral production (in comparison to surrounding deep-sea waters) implies that viruses are a significant source of microbial mortality at the vents.<ref name=":18" /> Like in other marine environments, deep-sea hydrothermal viruses affect abundance and diversity of [[Prokaryote|prokaryotes]] and therefore impact microbial biogeochemical cycling by [[Lysis|lysing]] their hosts to replicate.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Breitbart|first=Mya|date=2012-01-15|title=Marine Viruses: Truth or Dare|url=https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-marine-120709-142805|journal=Annual Review of Marine Science|language=en|volume=4|issue=1|pages=425–448|doi=10.1146/annurev-marine-120709-142805|issn=1941-1405}}</ref>
However, in contrast to their role as a source of mortality and population control, viruses have also been postulated to enhance survival of prokaryotes in extreme environments, acting as reservoirs of genetic information. The interactions of the virosphere with microorganisms under environmental stresses is therefore thought to aide microorganism survival through dispersal of host genes through [[Horizontal gene transfer in evolution|Horizontal Gene Transfer]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Goldenfeld|first=Nigel|last2=Woese|first2=Carl|date=January 2007|title=Biology's next revolution|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/445369a|journal=Nature|volume=445|issue=7126|pages=369–369|doi=10.1038/445369a|issn=0028-0836}}</ref><blockquote>“There's roughly [[Avogadro’s number]] of infections going on in the ocean, and every one of those interactions can result in the transfer of genetic information between virus and host” — Curtis Suttle<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn14575-new-viral-way-of-life-discovered-in-deep-sea-vents/|title=New viral way of life discovered in deep-sea vents|last=Callaway|first=Ewen|work=New Scientist|access-date=2018-11-14|language=en-US}}</ref> </blockquote>[[Temperate phage|Temperate phages]] (those not causing immediate lysis) can sometimes confer [[Phenotype|phenotypes]] that improve fitness in prokaryotes <sup>[7]</sup> The [[Lysogenic cycle|lysogenic]] life-cycle can persist stably for thousands of generations of infected bacteria and the viruses can alter the host's phenotype by enabling genes (a process known as [[lysogenic conversion]]) which can therefore allow hosts to cope with different environments.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Clokie|first=Martha R.J.|last2=Millard|first2=Andrew D.|last3=Letarov|first3=Andrey V.|last4=Heaphy|first4=Shaun|date=January 2011|title=Phages in nature|url=https://doi.org/10.4161/bact.1.1.14942|journal=Bacteriophage|language=en|volume=1|issue=1|pages=31–45|doi=10.4161/bact.1.1.14942|issn=2159-7081|pmc=3109452|pmid=21687533}}</ref> Benefits to the host population can also be conferred by expression of phage-encoded fitness-enhancing phenotypes.<ref name=":19">{{Cite journal|last=Williamson|first=Shannon J|last2=Cary|first2=S Craig|last3=Williamson|first3=Kurt E|last4=Helton|first4=Rebekah R|last5=Bench|first5=Shellie R|last6=Winget|first6=Danielle|last7=Wommack|first7=K Eric|date=2008-08-21|title=Lysogenic virus–host interactions predominate at deep-sea diffuse-flow hydrothermal vents|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/ismej200873|journal=The ISME Journal|language=En|volume=2|issue=11|pages=1112–1121|doi=10.1038/ismej.2008.73|issn=1751-7362}}</ref> [[File:Lysogentic cycle diagram.svg|thumb|Lysogenic Cycle: 1. The prokaryotic cell is shown with its DNA, in green. 2. The bacteriophage attaches and releases its DNA, shown in red, into the prokaryotic cell. 3. The phage DNA then moves through the cell to the host's DNA. 4. The phage DNA integrates itself into the host cell's DNA, creating prophage. 5. The prophage then remains dormant until the host cell divides. 6. After the host cell has duplicated, the phage DNA in the daughter cells activate, and the phage DNA begins to express itself. Some of the cells containing the prophage go on to create new phages which will move on to infect other cells.]] A review of viral work at hydrothermal vents published in 2015 stated that vents harbour a significant proportion of lysogenic hosts and that a large proportion of viruses are temperate indicating that the vent environments may provide an advantage to the prophage.<ref name=":20">{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/272147017_Viral_evolution_at_the_limits|title=(PDF) Viral evolution at the limits|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2018-11-14}}</ref>
One study of virus-host interactions in diffuse-flow hydrothermal vent environments found that the high-incidence of lysogenic hosts and large populations of temperate viruses was unique in its magnitude and that these viruses are likely critical to the systems ecology of prokaryotes. The same study's genetic analysis found that 51% of the viral [[Metagenomics|metagenome]] sequences were unknown (lacking [[Homology (biology)|homology]] to sequenced data), with high diversity across vent environments but lower diversity for specific vent sites which indicates high specificity for viral targets.<ref name=":19" />
A metagenomic analysis of deep-sea hydrothermal vent [[Virome|viromes]] showed that viral genes manipulated bacterial [[metabolism]], participating in metabolic pathways as well as forming branched pathways in microbial metabolism which facilitated adaptation to the extreme environment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=He|first=Tianliang|last2=Li|first2=Hongyun|last3=Zhang|first3=Xiaobo|date=2017-09-06|title=Deep-Sea Hydrothermal Vent Viruses Compensate for Microbial Metabolism in Virus-Host Interactions|url=https://mbio.asm.org/content/8/4/e00893-17|journal=mBio|language=en|volume=8|issue=4|pages=e00893–17|doi=10.1128/mBio.00893-17|issn=2150-7511|pmc=5513705|pmid=28698277}}</ref>
An example of this was associated with the sulfur-consuming bacterium SUP05. A study found that 15 of 18 viral genomes sequenced from samples of vent plumes contained genes closely related to an enzyme that the SUP05 [[Chemolithoautotroph|chemolithoautotrophs]] use to extract energy from sulfur compounds. The authors concluded that such phage genes ([[auxiliary metabolic genes]]) that are able to enhance the sulfur oxidation metabolism in their hosts could provide selective advantages to viruses (continued infection and replication).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anantharaman|first=Karthik|last2=Duhaime|first2=Melissa B.|last3=Breier|first3=John A.|last4=Wendt|first4=Kathleen A.|last5=Toner|first5=Brandy M.|last6=Dick|first6=Gregory J.|date=2014-05-16|title=Sulfur Oxidation Genes in Diverse Deep-Sea Viruses|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/344/6185/757|journal=Science|language=en|volume=344|issue=6185|pages=757–760|doi=10.1126/science.1252229|issn=0036-8075|pmid=24789974}}</ref> The similarity in viral and SUP05 genes for the sulfur metabolism implies an exchange of genes in the past and could implicate the viruses as agents of evolution.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/science/articles/2014/05/02/3996620.htm|title=Viruses make zombies of deep sea vent bacteria|date=2014-05-02|website=www.abc.net.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2018-11-14}}</ref>
Another metagenomic study found that viral genes had relatively high proportion of metabolism, [[Vitamin|vitamins]] and [[Cofactor (biochemistry)|cofactor]] genes, indicating that viral genomes encode auxiliary metabolic genes. Coupled with the observations of a high proportion of lysogenic viruses, this indicates that viruses are selected to be integrated [[Provirus|pro-viruses]] rather than free floating viruses and that the auxiliary genes can be expressed to benefit both the host and the integrated virus. The viruses enhance fitness by boosting metabolism or offering greater metabolic flexibility to the hosts they’re within. The evidence suggests that deep-sea hydrothermal vent viral evolutionary strategies promote prolonged host integration, favoring a form of mutualism to classic parasitism.<ref name=":17" />
As hydrothermal vents outlets for sub-seafloor material, there is also likely a connection between vent viruses and those in the crust.<ref name=":20" />
== References == <references />
[[Category:Organisms living on hydrothermal vents]] [[Category:Microbiology]]

{{more citations needed|date=November 2009}} {{Infobox company |name = IAV GmbH
Ingenieurgesellschaft Auto und Verkehr |logo = IAV claim-CO rgb.svg |logo_size = 220px|type = [[Limited liability company]]:
[[Gesellschaft mit beschränkter Haftung|GmbH]]{{cite web|url=http://www.iav.com/en/about-iav/iav-figures|title=IAV in Figures|work=IAV GmbH|publisher=IAV.com|date=January 2014|accessdate=5 November 2014}} |foundation = [[Berlin]], Germany (1983) |founder = Prof. Dr. [[Hermann Appel]] |location = [[Berlin]], Germany |locations = 16 operations across Germany, several Subsidiaries |area_served = Worldwide |key_people = Matthias Kratzsch,
[[President (corporate title)|President]], [[chief executive officer|CEO]];{{cite web|url=http://www.iav.com/en/press/iav-management|title=IAV Management|work=IAV GmbH|publisher=IAV.com|accessdate=5 November 2014}}
Kai-Stefan Linnenkohl,
President, [[Chief Human Resources Officer|CHRO]] |industry = [[Automotive industry]] |products = |services = Powertrain, Electronics and Vehicle Development |revenue = 798 million [[Euro]] (2017) |operating_income = |net_income = |assets = |equity = |owner = |num_employees = 7,000 worldwide (2017) |parent = |divisions = |subsid = |homepage = [http://www.IAV.com IAV.com] |footnotes = }} '''IAV GmbH''' ({{lang-de|'''Ingenieurgesellschaft Auto und Verkehr'''}}, literal ''Engineer Society Automobile and Traffic''), abbreviated to '''IAV''', is an [[engineering]] company in the [[automotive industry]], designing products for [[powertrain]], [[electronics]] and [[vehicle development]]. Founded in [[Berlin]] in 1983 by Prof. Dr. Hermann Appel as a university-affiliated research institute, the company employs over 7,000 members of staff, and supplies [[automotive industry|automobile manufacturers]] and [[component supplier]]s. In addition to development centres in Berlin, [[Chemnitz]] and [[Gifhorn]], IAV operates at sites in France, United Kingdom, Italy, Russia, China, India, Japan, [[South Korea]], [[Brazil]], Mexico and the United States. Clients include the [[Volkswagen Group]], [[BMW]], [[PSA Peugeot Citroën]], [[Fiat]], [[Ford Motor Company]], [[General Motors]], [[Porsche]] and [[Toyota]].{{cite web|url=http://www.iav.com/en/about-iav/clients|title=Our Clients|work=IAV GmbH|publisher=IAV.com|accessdate=1 November 2013}} Component manufacturer clients include [[Robert Bosch GmbH]], [[Delphi (auto parts)|Delphi]], [[Continental AG]] and [[ZF Friedrichshafen|ZF Group]]. ==Shareholders== {{As of|2013}} the [[shareholder]]s of IAV GmbH were: *[[Volkswagen Group]] - 50% *[[Continental AG|Continental Automotive GmbH]] - 20% *[[Schaeffler Group|Schaeffler Technologies AG & Co. KG]] - 10% *[[Freudenberg Group|Freudenberg & Co. KG]] - 10% *[[SABIC|SABIC Innovative Plastics B.V.]] - 10% ==Subsidiaries== IAV has the following worldwide [[subsidiary]] companies: ;Europe *Consulting4Drive GmbH, Berlin *IAV S.A.S.U. (France) *IAV Cars GmbH *IAV Rus, LLC (Russia) *IAV U.K. Ltd. *IAV Fahrzeugsicherheit GmbH & Co. KG, Gifhorn *TR Engineering powered by IAV GmbH, Neustadt/Weinstraße ;Asia *IAV Automotive Engineering (Shanghai) Co. Ltd. *IAV India Private Ltd. *IAV Japan Co. Ltd. *IAV Korea Co. Ltd. ;North / South America *IAV Automotive Engineering Inc. (USA) *IAV do Brasil Ltda. *IAV Automotive Engineering de México == In-road electric vehicle charger == In 2009 the company submitted a patent for an [[electric vehicle]] recharger that is built into the road. The technology would allow electric vehicles to be charged as they drive over roads embedded with a recessed wireless recharging strip, using [[inductive charging|electromagnetic induction]].[http://www.technovelgy.com/ct/Science-Fiction-News.asp?NewsNum=2591 In-Road Electric Vehicle Charger : Science Fiction in the News] == See also == * [[Ground-level power supply]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.IAV.com IAV.com] official international portal {{Volkswagen Group brands}} [[Category:Automotive companies of Germany]] [[Category:Automotive engineering]] [[Category:Electric vehicle industry]] [[Category:Charging stations]] [[Category:Companies established in 1983]] [[Category:Volkswagen Group]] [[Category:Companies based in Berlin]]

{{Infobox Person | name = Professor Jane Hunter | citizenship = [[Australia]]n | employer = [[The University of Queensland]] | title = Professorial [[Research Fellow]] | education =[[PhD]] ([[Computer Science]]) ([[Cambridge University|Cambridge]]),
B. Eng ([[Metallurgical]]) (UQ) (1A Hons),
B.Sc (Materials) (UQ) | image = | alt = Image of Professor Jane Hunter | caption = Photo of Professor Jane Hunter }} Professor '''Jane Hunter''' is the Director of [[University of Queensland]]'s e-Research Lab and Chair of the [[Australian Academy of Science]]'s National Committee for Data in Science; Vice-President of the National Executive Committee for [[Digital Humanities]]; and Member of Scientific Committee of the [[ICSU World Data System]].{{cite web|url=http://staff.itee.uq.edu.au/jane/index.html |title=Information about Jane Hunter |publisher=Staff.itee.uq.edu.au |date= |accessdate=2014-08-14}} [[E-research]] has emerged through the exponential expansion of information technologies. New online tools, networks, data capture, management and visualisation techniques are needed to enhance collaboration and data sharing between researchers who need access to very large data collections, high-performance analysis and modelling particularly across disciplines.{{cite web|url=http://www.itee.uq.edu.au/eresearch|title=eResearch|website=eResearch}} Her research projects cover a wide range of topics and include the OzTrack Project looking at how to store, analyse and visualise animal tracking data;[https://nrelscience.org/2014/02/25/a-report-from-the-international-digital-curation-conference-idcc14/ "A Report from the International Digital Curation Conference"]. ''EcoPress'', Nicole Kaplan The Twentieth Century in Paint a multidisciplinary project to inform the preservation of [[modern art]]; HuNI - Humanities Networked Infrastructure applying new data tools to integrate [[Australia|Australia's]] most significant cultural datasets for humanities researchers. In speaking of a joint project on Queensland's waterways, Professor Hunter notes, 'There is a massive amount of monitoring data being collected, and Health-e-Waterways provides a high-tech approach to turning that data into meaningful information".{{cite web|url=http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/collaboration/global/asia-pacific/regions/australia.aspx|title=Academic Programs - Microsoft Research|website=microsoft.com}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *http://staff.itee.uq.edu.au/jane/index.html *http://www.itee.uq.edu.au/eresearch *http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/collaboration/global/asia-pacific/regions/australia.aspx *[http://researchers.uq.edu.au/researcher/1603 list of Professor Hunter's publications] {{DEFAULTSORT:Hunter, Jane}} [[Category:Women data scientists]] [[Category:Australian women scientists]] [[Category:21st-century women scientists]] [[Category:Digital humanities]] [[Category:University of Queensland faculty]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.text:
'''Johann Jakob Griesbach''' (4 January 1745 – 24 March 1812), German biblical [[textual critic]], was born at [[Butzbach]], a small town in the state of [[Landgraviate of Hesse-Darmstadt|Hesse-Darmstadt]], where his father, Konrad Kaspar (1705–1777), was pastor. Griesbach's fame rests upon his work in [[New Testament]] criticism, in which he inaugurated a new epoch. His solution to the [[synoptic problem]] bears his name, but the [[Griesbach hypothesis]] has been modernly referred to as the [[Two-Gospel hypothesis]]. [[File:Griesbach1.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Johann Jakob Griesbach]]
==Education and career== Griesbach was educated at [[Frankfurt]], and at the universities of [[university of Tübingen|Tübingen]], [[university of Leipzig|Leipzig]] and [[university of Halle|Halle]], where he became one of [[Johann Salomo Semler|J. S. Semler]]'s most ardent disciples. It was Semler who induced him to turn his attention to the textual criticism of the New Testament. At the close of his undergraduate career he undertook a literary tour through Germany, the Netherlands, France and England. In England he may have met [[Henry Owen]] whose seminal work ''Observations on the Four Gospels'' (1764) is listed among the books of Griesbach's estate, although he does not seem to have acknowledged any indebtedness to Owen.
On his return to Halle, Griesbach acted for some time as ''Privatdozent'', but in 1773 was appointed to a professorial chair; in 1775 he went to the [[Friedrich Schiller University of Jena|University of Jena]], where he spent the rest of his life (though he received calls to other universities).
==New Testament text critic== [[File:Johann Jacob Griesbach.jpg|thumb]] Griesbach's critical edition of the [[New Testament]] first appeared at Halle, in three volumes, in 1774-1775. The first volume contained the first three Gospels, synoptically arranged; the second, the [[Epistles]] and the [[book of Revelation]]. All the historical books were reprinted in one volume in 1777, the synoptical arrangement of the Gospels having been abandoned as inconvenient. Of the second edition, considerably enlarged and improved, the first volume appeared in 1796 and the second in 1806 (Halle and London). Of a third edition, edited by David Schulz, only the first volume, containing the four Gospels, appeared (1827).
For the construction of his critical text Griesbach took as his basis the [[House of Elzevir|''Elzevir'']] edition. Where he differed from it he placed the ''Elzevir'' reading on the inner margin along with other readings he thought worthy of special consideration (these last, however, being printed in smaller type). To all the readings on this margin he attached special marks indicating the precise degree of probability in his opinion attaching to each. In weighing these probabilities he proceeded upon a particular theory which in its leading features he had derived from [[Johann Albrecht Bengel|J. A. Bengel]] and J. S. Semler, dividing all the manuscripts into three main groups – the [[Alexandria]]n, the Western and the [[Byzantium|Byzantine]].
A reading supported by only one [[recension]] he considered as having only one witness in its favour; those readings which were supported by all the three recensions, or even by two of them, especially if these two were the Alexandrian and the Western, he unhesitatingly accepted as genuine. Only when each of the three recensions gives a different reading does he proceed to discuss the question on other grounds.
See his ''Symbolae criticae ad supplendas et corrigendas variarum N. T. lectionum collectiones'' (Halle, 1785, 1793), and his ''Commentarius criticus in textum Graecum N. T.'', which extends to the end of [[Gospel of Mark|Mark]] and discusses the more important various readings with great care and thoroughness (Jena, 1794 if.).
Among the other works of Griesbach (which are comparatively unimportant) may be mentioned his university thesis ''De codicibus quatuor evangelislarum Origenianis'' (Halle, 1771) and a work upon [[systematic theology]] (''Anleitung zur Kenntniss der populären Dogmatik'', Jena, 1779). His ''Opuscula'', consisting chiefly of university "Programs" and addresses, were edited by [[Johann Philipp Gabler|Gabler]] (2 vols, Jena, 1824).
==Gospel Synopsis== In 1776 Griesbach published his Greek Gospel synopsis of Matthew, Mark and Luke as a volume separate from his critical edition of the New Testament (cf. above), of which it had previously been a part, and thereby established the tool of a synopsis as an essential research aid in New Testament studies.
For Griesbach's hypothesis concerning the interrelation of the Gospel accounts of Matthew, Mark and Luke, and its modern variant, see [[Griesbach hypothesis]].
==Johann Jakob Griesbach Bicentenary Colloquium 1776-1976== To mark the bicentenary of the publication of Griesbach's Gospel synopsis as a separate volume a group of distinguished international biblical scholars met in July 1976 at Münster/Westphalia for ''The Johann Jakob Griesbach Bicentenary Colloquium 1776-1976''.
A selection of the papers presented at the colloquium appraising Griesbach's life, work and influence, aimed "to indicate why an understanding of this scholar's contribution to New Testament criticism is important both for the history of New Testament scholarship and for contemporary research", together with the text in Latin and in English translation of ''The Dissertation of J. J. Griesbach, Doctor of Theology and Principal Professor in the University of Jena, in which he demonstrates that the entire Gospel of Mark has been extracted from the Gospels of Matthew and Luke, written in the name of the University of Jena (1789–1790), now revised and furnished with many additions'', are to be found in [[Bernard Orchard]] and [[Thomas R. W. Longstaff]] (ed.), ''J. J. Griesbach: Synoptic and Text-Critical Studies 1776-1976'', Volume 34 in the SNTS Monograph Series (Cambridge University Press, hardback 1978, paperback 2005 {{ISBN|0-521-02055-7}}).
== Works ==
* {{Cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=PqcUAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false | title = Symbolae criticae ad supplendas et corrigendas variarum N. T. lectionum collectiones | location = Halle | year = 1793}} * {{Cite book | url = https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&id=BLk9AAAAIAAJ&dq=graece&printsec=frontcover&source | title = Novum Testamentum Graece. IV Evangelia | location = Londini | year = 1809 | volume = I}} * [https://archive.org/details/hkaindiathknovu01unkngoog ''Hē kainē diathēkē: Novum Testamentum Graece''] (1817) * {{Cite book | author = | url = https://archive.org/details/novumtestamentum02grie | title = Novum Testamentum Graece. Actas et Epistolas Apostolorum cum Apocalypsi | location = Londini | year = 1818 | volume = II}} * [https://archive.org/details/hkaindiathknovu00griegoog ''Hē Kainē Diathēkē: Novum Testamentum graece. Cura Leusdenii et Griesbachii''] (1823) * [https://archive.org/details/fourgospelsnewt00griegoog ''The four Gospels of the New Testament, in Greek, from the text of Griesbach''] (1825)
==See also== * [[Gospel harmony]]
==References== * {{EB1911|wstitle=Griesbach, Johann Jakob}} This work in turn cites: ** Herzog-Hauck, ''Realencyklopädie'' ** {{Cite ADB|9|660|663|Griesbach, Johann Jacob|Carl Bertheau|ADB:Griesbach, Johann Jakob}}
== External links == * {{BBKL|g/griesbach_j_j|band=2|autor=Friedrich Wilhelm Bautz|pages=350–351}} * [https://archive.org/stream/hkaindiathkgrie00bassgoog#page/n14/mode/2up ''Hē Kainē Diathēkē: Griesbach's text, with the various readings of Mill and Scholz''] (London 1859)
{{Authority control}}
